titleStmt.title: Improved Stability Condition for Takagi-Sugeno Fuzzy Systems With Time-Varying Delay

affiliation.orgName: School of Computing, Engineering and Mathematics
School of Computing, Engineering and Mathematics

analytic.title: Improved Stability Condition for Takagi-Sugeno Fuzzy Systems With Time-Varying Delay

biblStruct.note: received August 22, 2015; revised December 10, 2015; accepted January 26, 2016.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: In this paper, the stability analysis problem of Takagi-Sugeno fuzzy systems with time-varying delay is investigated. By utilizing the Wirtinger-based integral inequality and the improved reciprocally convex combination technique, an improved stability condition is derived in terms of linear matrix inequalities. A numerical example is given to demonstrate the efficiency of the obtained result.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: T IME-DELAY is of significance both in theory and appli- cation due to its detrimental effects on stability and performance of systems and its wide existence in practical dynamic processes. Considerable effort has been made to obtain delay-dependent stability results during the past decades [1]- [4]. Moreover, reducing the conservatism of the stability results has received increasing attention and many improved approaches have been proposed, such as the free-weighting matrices method [5], the delay-partitioning method [6], the integral partitioning method [7] (which partitions the integral interval into m uniform subintervals), the convex combination approach [8], the triple integral approach [9], the input-output approach [10], the reciprocally convex combination approach [11], the mixed convex combination approach [12], and Wirtinger-based integral inequality [13]. In particular, the reciprocally convex combination approach, which tackles the inversely weighted convex combination of quadratic terms of integral quantities directly and can be proved to be less conservative than Jensen inequality, has been extensively applied to different systems, such as neural networks [14] and Markovian jump systems [15]. However, there is room to improve the reciprocally combination approach to obtain less conservative results. On the other hand, the reciprocally combination approach has been only used to estimate single integral and how to employ it to bound double integral is not discussed in the aforementioned existing results.

Takagi-Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy model proposed in [16] has provided a powerful control methodology for nonlinear systems and it has been extensively applied in many practical systems [17]- [22]. A systematic study of modeling, identification, and control of fuzzy systems is given in [23] and [24]. The existing stability results of time-delay T-S fuzzy systems are generally obtained based on two types of theories: 1) the Lyapunov-Krasovskii stability theory [25], [26] which is widely used and 2) the Lyapunov-Razumikhin method [27] which uses less information of time-delay and thus can be more conservative.

The T-S fuzzy systems with time-varying delay can be classified into two categories: the discrete-time case [28] and continuous-time case [29]. For discrete-time T-S fuzzy systems with time-varying delay, a novel approach to stability and stabilization is introduced in [30], where it is shown that the results are much less conservative than most of the existing results due to the developed delay partitioning technique. Dissipativity analysis and synthesis for discrete-time T-S fuzzy stochastic systems with time-varying delay are investigated in [31], and the methods employed to derive the dissipativity analysis conditions are efficient and less conservative, thus facilitating the controller design. In addition, the results obtained in [31] provide an alternative way to deal with the dissipativity analysis and synthesis for nonlinear systems in a T-S fuzzy framework, which is important.

For continuous-time T-S fuzzy systems with time-varying delay, several approaches such as the free-weighting matrices, the delay-partitioning method, the convex combination approach and the input-output technique, have been proposed to obtain stability criteria. By utilizing the free-weighting matrices technique and the Lyapunov functional method, sufficient condition for the asymptotical stability is obtained in [29]. A simpler analysis method with fewer free-weighting matrices is proposed in [32] to improve the stability criterion of [29]. Furthermore, introducing some integral inequalities and adding some free variables make the stability criteria in [33] more relaxed and less conservative than those of [32]. By introducing triple integral term into Lyapunov functional, stability and stabilization criteria are proposed in [34]. Benefiting from the delay-partitioning and reciprocally 2168-2267 c 2016 IEEE. Personal use is permitted, but republication/redistribution requires IEEE permission.
See http://www.ieee.org/publications_standards/publications/rights/index.html for more information.

convex combination approaches, improved delay-dependent results for T-S fuzzy system are presented in [35]. The reciprocally convex combination approach is also employed to study the stability criterion of delay T-S fuzzy systems in [21]. Different from linear convex combination and reciprocally convex combination, the quadratic convex combination originally proposed in [36] is applied to derive less conservative stability results in [20] and sampled-data stabilization results in [12]. An input-output approach is used in [10] to reduce the conservatism of stability results efficiently for discrete-time systems with time-varying delay. Later on, the input-output approach is successfully extended to robust stability and stabilization problems for T-S fuzzy systems with time-varying delay in [37] and the results obtained therein further improve those of [33]. Recently, a less conservative stability criterion for delay T-S fuzzy systems is proposed in [38] by using partial nonpositive Lyapunov functional with triple integral terms. However, the estimates of single integrals and double integrals in [38] are attained by using Jensen inequality which is more conservative than that of the reciprocally convex combination approach. Therefore, there still exist rooms for further improvements by enlarging the allowable maximum upper bound of delay for T-S fuzzy systems.

In this paper, we propose an improved stability criterion of continuous T-S fuzzy systems with time-varying delay. By constructing a Lyapunov functional with triple integral terms and utilizing the improved reciprocally convex combination approach and Wirtinger-based integral inequality, a new sufficient stability condition is developed in terms of linear matrix inequalities (LMIs). A numerical example is included to validate the workability of the presented results in comparison with the existing results. The main contribution of this paper is to provide a less conservative stability criterion of delay T-S fuzzy systems by employing an improved reciprocally convex combination approach for bounding single integrals and utilizing second-order reciprocally convex combination for bounding double integrals.

The rest of this paper is briefly outlined as follows. In Section II, the stability problem is formulated. An improved sufficient stability condition is presented in Section III. To illustrate the reduced conservatism and the improved effectiveness, a numerical example is provided in Section IV. This paper is concluded in Section V.

div.head: A. Notation
div.p: The notation used throughout this paper is standard. R n denotes the n-dimensional Euclidean space; P > 0 (≥ 0) means that matrix P is real symmetric and positive definite (semi-positive definite); I and 0 denote the identity matrix and zero matrix, respectively, with compatible dimensions; stands for the symmetric terms in a symmetric matrix; sym(A) is defined as A + A T ; diag{M, N} stands for a block-diagonal matrix composed by matrices M and N; and C m n means n!/m!(nm)!, where n! is the factorial function. Matrices are assumed to be compatible for algebraic operations if their dimensions are not explicitly stated.

div.head: II. PRELIMINARIES Consider a nonlinear system with time-delay which can be represented by the following T-S fuzzy time-delay model by:
div.p: Plant Rule i (i = 1, 2, . . . , r):
div.formula: IF θ 1 is μ i1 , and • • • and θ p is μ ip THEN ẋ(t) = A i x(t) + A di x(t -h(t)) x(t) = φ(t), t ∈ [-h 2 , 0](1)
div.p: where By using the commonly used center-average defuzzifier, product interferences and singleton fuzzifier, the T-S fuzzy system (1) can be inferred as
div.formula: ẋ(t) = r i=1 λ i (θ (t))[A i x(t) + A di x(t -h(t))] (2
div.p: where θ(t) = [θ 1 (t), . . . , θ p (t)] and
div.formula: λ i (θ (t)) = w i (θ (t)) r i=1 w i (θ (t)) ≥ 0 w i (θ (t)) = p j=1 μ ij θ j (t)
div.p: with μ ij (θ j (t)) representing the grade of membership of θ j (t) in μ ij . It can be seen that
For simplicity, λ i will be used to denote λ i (θ (t)) without confusion.
The aim of this paper is to establish a less conservative stability criterion for T-S fuzzy system (2). Before presenting the main result, the following lemmas are given first.
div.formula: Lemma 1: Let f 1 , f 2 : R m → R have positive values in an open subset D of R m . div.p: Proof: The prescribed constraint implies inequality (3), shown at the top of this page, where [g 1,2 (t)] a means that the row of g 1,2 (t) is the same as that of C a n f 1 (t) and the column of g 1,2 (t) is the same as that of C a n f 2 (t) with a = (n -1)/2 when n is odd and a = (n/2) when n is even. Then we have

div.p: Remark 1: Lemma 1 is largely inspired by [11]. It can be utilized to bound the nth order reciprocally convex combination. In this sense, it generalizes the results in [11].
Following the similar lines as those in [9], the following more generalized lemma is obtained.

div.head: III. MAIN RESULTS
div.p: In this section, the stability analysis problem for T-S fuzzy system with time-varying delay is considered by utilizing Wirtinger-based integral inequality and the improved reciprocally convex combination method.

Remark 2: The Lyapunov function constructed in ( 7) is more general. Specially speaking, this is because several augmented vectors such as ε(t), ζ 1 (s), ζ 2 (s), and ζ 3 (s) are applied.

div.p: ẋT (s)R 2 ẋ(s)dsdθ dλ are to be discussed in Remark 3. Moreover, the delaypartitioning method is also utilized in constructing the Lyapunov functional, such as
div.formula: t t-(h 1 /2) ζ T 1 (s)Q 1 ζ 1 (s)ds and t t-(h 1 /2) ζ T 2 (s)Q 4 ζ 2 (s)ds, which makes x(t -(h 1 /2)), t t-(h 1 /2) x(s)ds, t-(h 1 /2) t-h 1
div.p: x(s)ds, and 2) x(s)ds appear in ξ(t) in addition to containing the traditional terms x(th 1 ) and t t-h 1 x(s)ds. Thus, more time-delay information is applied in the delay-partitioning method adopted here and less conservative results will be obtained. The reduced conservatism benefits from the general Lyapunov functional discussed above. However, the positive definiteness of the matrix P in V(x(t)) is needed which will inevitably induce the conservatism. On the other hand, only bi-partitioning methods are employed and the improved results will be expected if the lower bound of delay is partitioned into multiple segments.
Remark 3: Generally speaking, the triple integral term
div.formula: χ 1 (x(t)) = h 2 12 2 -h 1 -h 2 -h 1 λ t t+θ ẋT (s)R 2 ẋ(s)dsdθ dλ introduced in V 4 (x(t)) is better than the term χ 2 (x(t)) = h 2 2 -h 2 1 2 -h 1 -h 2 0 λ t t+θ ẋT (s)R 2 ẋ(s)dsdθ dλ
div.p: because the more information of lower bound delay h 1 is utilized in the inner integral upper limit of χ 1 (x(t)) [41]. More specifically, the nonnegative terms of derivative of χ ẋT (s)R 2 ẋ(s)ds appears in χ1 (x(t)) which makes the condition S R > 0 necessary in the derivation of (12). If there is not the term

ẋT (s)R 2 ẋ(s)ds, then the condition S 2 > 0 is needed. It can be seen that S R > 0 is easier to satisfy than S 2 > 0. On the other hand, the second-order reciprocally convex combination approach is used to deal with the double integral terms of χ1 (x(t)) with the condition R 2 > 0, which is better than the condition

Remark 4: To illustrate the improvement of the reciprocally convex combination approach, let us give an example to estimate -h 12 t-h 1 t-h 2 ζ T 3 (s)S 2 ζ 3 (s)ds, which is the last term in (12). If the well-known Jensen inequality is employed, then the bounding inequality is given by (19) where the symbols ζ 3 (s), ξ(t), and W 3 -W 10 are defined in Theorem 1 and they are omitted here. By using the reciprocally convex combination approach proposed in [11], the integral is bounded as

Therefore, when X = S 2 , the inequality in (20) reduces to the inequality in (19), which implies that the feasible region of the reciprocally convex combination approach is larger than that of Jensen inequality. However, by introducing two zero equations ( 14) and ( 15), the single integral is estimated as [that is the inequality in ( 16)]

It can be clearly seen that inequality (21) reduces to inequality (20) when P 1 = P 2 = 0. Therefore, the feasible region of the stability criterion obtained by using inequality (21) can improve those obtained by using Jensen inequalities (19) and (20). The reciprocally convex combination approach used in this paper to estimate single integral is an improved version. Moreover, the reciprocally convex combination approach is applied to estimate the double integral

ẋT (s)R 2 ẋ(s)dsdθ . This extension is not straightforward because the second-order reciprocally convex combination, which is given in Lemma 1, should be utilized. The detailed process can refer to the inequalities in ( 13) and (17) in the above.
Remark 5: In the derivation of (17
div.formula: ), if the matrix R 2 Y Y R 2 is not decomposed to -R 2 0 0 -R 2 and R 2 , then the constraint R 2 Y Y
div.p: R 2 > 0 will be added in order to use Lemma 3. By decomposing the matrix, a less conservative condition R 2 > 0, which is just the condition of the secondorder reciprocally convex combination approach, is needed to utilize Lemma 3. Remark 6: Note that the number of decision variables in Theorem 1 is 42.5n 2 + 8.5n.

Remark 7: The main purpose and contributions of this paper is to propose a less conservative stability criterion for T-S fuzzy systems with time-varying delay. To this end, the nth order reciprocally convex combination approach is provided in Lemma 1, which is more general than the reciprocally convex combination and the second-order reciprocally convex combination approach. Moreover, the reciprocally convex combination is used to bound the double integral terms. In addition, the delay-partitioning method and the improved reciprocally convex combination technique are also combined together.

div.head: IV. NUMERICAL EXAMPLE
div.p: In this section, a numerical example is given to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed result.
Consider the following nonlinear system with time-varying delay:
The nonlinear system (22) can be modeled as a T-S fuzzy system with time-varying delay by using the same rules as in [32], which are given as follows:
Plant Rule 1: IF θ(t) is ±(π/2), THEN ẋ = A 1 x(t) + A d1 x(th(t)).
Plant Rule 2: If θ(t) is 0, THEN ẋ = A 2 x(t) + A d2 x(th(t))
where , λ 2 (θ (t)) = 1 -λ 1 (θ (t)).
div.formula: A
div.p: This system is considered in [32], [33], [35], [37], and [38]. When μ = 0.1 and h 1 = 1, the T-S fuzzy system is stable when h(t) ≤ 1.4841 and h(t) ≤ 1.4860 by utilizing the results in [32] and [33], respectively. For the recent publication [37], when choosing the fuzzy weighting-dependent parameter β i = 5 × 10 k , i = 1, . . . , r, k = 1, 2, . . . , the allowable maximal values of h 2 are 1.4986 and 1.6267 with the delay-partitioning number m = 1 and m = 3, respectively. When β i = 0.5, i = 1, . . . , r, the improved upper bound of time-varying delay can reach h 2 = 1.5253 and h 2 = 1.6695 under the conditions m = 1 and m = 3, respectively, in [37]. By solving the LMIs in our Theorem 1, the allowable maximum delay h 2 is found to be 1.8106, which further improves the results obtained in [37].

In order to compare different existing methods with the results in Theorem 1 of this paper, the allowable maximal values of h 2 are listed in Table I with μ = 0.1 and different h 1 . From Table I, it can be seen that the better results are obtained by the method given in this paper. In order to illustrate the applicability of the obtained results, Fig. 1 is depicted to show the stability of the considered system. Considering the case . From Fig. 1, it can be observed that the considered system is asymptotically stable.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: The stability problem of T-S fuzzy systems with timevarying delay has been studied in this paper. An improved stability condition in terms of strict LMIs has been proposed by employing Wirtinger-based integral inequality together with the improved reciprocally convex combination technique, which reduces the conservatism of existing results. The improvement and effectiveness of the proposed method have been illustrated by a numerical example. Finally, how to apply the Wirtinger-based inequality to bound the double integral term to further improve the obtained results and study the delay case with zero lower bound are interesting topics, which will be considered in our future work.
